answers.body_markdown:
It looks like this is caused by the `/error` page being under the control of Spring Security.  The 404 was properly thrown, and I'm going to assume that you don't have any ControllerAdvice defined for handling the 404, so you go redirected to the default error handler page, which is `/error` and handled by the `BasicErrorController`.  There's a line in your logs just above that redirect that says something like setting SecurityContextHolder to anonymous.  So, your authentication is being cleared from the SecurityContext and you're being redirected to a page under lock and key, hence the 403.

Try adding `/error` to your list of permitAll methods and see if you get through.  Then it's just a matter of tuning your security configuration to suit your needs.
answers.title: Spring Boot - Any exception in @RestController returns 403 - even if I throw a 404
answers.body:
It looks like this is caused by the /error page being under the control of Spring Security. The 404 was properly thrown, and I'm going to assume that you don't have any ControllerAdvice defined for handling the 404, so you go redirected to the default error handler page, which is /error and handled by the BasicErrorController. There's a line in your logs just above that redirect that says something like setting SecurityContextHolder to anonymous. So, your authentication is being cleared from the SecurityContext and you're being redirected to a page under lock and key, hence the 403.

Try adding /error to your list of permitAll methods and see if you get through. Then it's just a matter of tuning your security configuration to suit your needs.

answers.body_markdown:
I had the exact same issue, and of all the alternatives listed in [this very helpful overview](https://stackabuse.com/how-to-return-http-status-codes-in-a-spring-boot-application/), I could initially only get this one to work: wrap the return type in `ResponseEntity<T>`:

```java
@GetMapping
@PreAuthorize("hasAnyRole('ADMIN')")
public ResponseEntity<UserDetail> getAllUserData(@RequestParam ...) {
    ....
    if (userDetail == null) {
        return new ResponseEntity<UserDetail>(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND);
    } else {
        return new ResponseEntity<UserDetail>(userDetail, HttpStatus.OK);
    }
}
```

Workable, but seems a bit ugly to have to change your method return types - though one could also argue that this is only fair: we _are_ implementing a REST controller, and an entity plus statuscode is exactly what REST methods should return. 

However, the [other answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/76328395/2109137) gave me the hint for how to solve this while sticking with `@ResponseStatus` and `ResponseStatusException`.

What appears to be happening is that Spring Boot, upon handling your exception, forwards control to an error dispatcher, for which the authenticated user is not authorised. The `403 FORBIDDEN` we see is the result of that.

This can be solved as follows in your `SecurityFilterChain`:  

```java
public SecurityFilterChain filterChain(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
    http
        ...
        .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
            .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated()
            .requestMatchers(...)           // or on your methods
            .anyRequest().authenticated())  // or denyAll() if all requestMatchers are above
        ...
```

Thus permitting access to the error dispatcher.

Update: I just noticed [this relevant warning](https://docs.spring.io/spring-framework/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/web/bind/annotation/ResponseStatus.html) in the javadoc for `@ResponseStatus`:

> **Warning:** when using this annotation on an exception class, or when setting the reason attribute of this annotation, the `HttpServletResponse.sendError` method will be used.
>
>With `HttpServletResponse.sendError`, the response is considered complete and should not be written to any further. Furthermore, the Servlet container will typically write an HTML error page therefore making the use of a reason unsuitable for REST APIs. For such cases it is preferable to use a `ResponseEntity` as a return type and avoid the use of `@ResponseStatus` altogether.

This argues against using `ResponseStatusException` altogether, though I wonder if this advice still applies to a modern day `@RestController`. I could imagine that _"the Servlet container will typically write an HTML error page"_ no longer necessarily holds, esp. under Spring Boot.

**Update (again)**

[This post](https://www.baeldung.com/exception-handling-for-rest-with-spring) confirms my last point: Spring Boot 5 handles `ResponseStatusException` correctly, with its default whitelabel error page preempting the Servlet container's handling (provided you keep `server.error.whitelabel.enabled` at its default `true`).

You'll still need the `.dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated()` in your filter chain.

You may want to set `server.error.include-message=always`, if you need your exception message to go back to the client. By default, the `message` field in the response entity is omitted for security reasons.

Finally, there's also `server.error.include-stacktrace` and `include-binding-errors` to get the full monty.

**Update (last one)**

After some testing it seems that this:

> You'll still need the `.dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated()` in your filter chain.

is true only if your filter chain ends with an `anyRequest.denyAll()`. Apparently, the thrown exception is considered a mismatch, and the deny kicks in with a forward to the `ERROR` dispatcher. 

So, with request matching in the chain, this is how to make it work:

```java
    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated()
        .requestMatchers("/user/**").hasRole("ADMIN")
        ...
        .anyRequest().denyAll())
```

Or alternatively, replace the `denyAll()` with `authenticated()` and you can omit the `ERROR` authorisation:

```java
    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .requestMatchers("/user/**").hasRole("ADMIN")
        ...
        .anyRequest().authenticated())
```

Which has the additional advantage that it also works for method security.  You couldn't have that `denyAll()` there (it would make all your methods unreachable) unless you precede it by a (broader) `requestMatcher`.

In fact, if you work strictly with method security, then simply this will do:

```java
    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .anyRequest().authenticated())
```

which I believe is the default anyway, so can be omitted altogether.

Thus permitting access to the error dispatcher.

Update: I just noticed this relevant warning in the javadoc for @ResponseStatus:

Warning: when using this annotation on an exception class, or when setting the reason attribute of this annotation, the HttpServletResponse.sendError method will be used.

With HttpServletResponse.sendError, the response is considered complete and should not be written to any further. Furthermore, the Servlet container will typically write an HTML error page therefore making the use of a reason unsuitable for REST APIs. For such cases it is preferable to use a ResponseEntity as a return type and avoid the use of @ResponseStatus altogether.

This argues against using ResponseStatusException altogether, though I wonder if this advice still applies to a modern day @RestController. I could imagine that "the Servlet container will typically write an HTML error page" no longer necessarily holds, esp. under Spring Boot.

Update (again)

This post confirms my last point: Spring Boot 5 handles ResponseStatusException correctly, with its default whitelabel error page preempting the Servlet container's handling (provided you keep server.error.whitelabel.enabled at its default true).

You'll still need the .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated() in your filter chain.

You may want to set server.error.include-message=always, if you need your exception message to go back to the client. By default, the message field in the response entity is omitted for security reasons.

Finally, there's also server.error.include-stacktrace and include-binding-errors to get the full monty.

Update (last one)

After some testing it seems that this:

You'll still need the .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated() in your filter chain.

is true only if your filter chain ends with an anyRequest.denyAll(). Apparently, the thrown exception is considered a mismatch, and the deny kicks in with a forward to the ERROR dispatcher.

So, with request matching in the chain, this is how to make it work:

    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).authenticated()
        .requestMatchers("/user/**").hasRole("ADMIN")
        ...
        .anyRequest().denyAll())

Or alternatively, replace the denyAll() with authenticated() and you can omit the ERROR authorisation:

    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .requestMatchers("/user/**").hasRole("ADMIN")
        ...
        .anyRequest().authenticated())

Which has the additional advantage that it also works for method security. You couldn't have that denyAll() there (it would make all your methods unreachable) unless you precede it by a (broader) requestMatcher.

In fact, if you work strictly with method security, then simply this will do:

    .authorizeHttpRequests(req -> req
        .anyRequest().authenticated())

which I believe is the default anyway, so can be omitted altogether.

items.title: Spring Boot - Any exception in @RestController returns 403 - even if I throw a 404
items.body:
EDIT:

The fix for me for this was to re-do the configuration for Spring Security - I'm not exactly sure what fixed it but the old config I was using did not work with the new Spring.

So, I really just started over with the new docs and re-wrote my config methods for Spring Security.

END EDIT

I have a Spring Boot app - newly updated version of Spring Boot - that started returning 403 to my client no matter what the REST controller throws. I have this:

@GetMapping
@PreAuthorize("hasAnyRole('ADMIN')")
fun getAllUserData(@RequestParam("start") start: Long = 0, @RequestParam("end") end: Long = 2684276745101): List<UserLog> {
    throw(NotFoundException())  // Method works without this line
    return userLogMapper.findFirst(maxRows, start, end)
}

@ResponseStatus(code = HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND)
class NotFoundException : RuntimeException()

answers.body_markdown:
Perhaps the easiest solution is to build a collection of date formats you can reasonably expect, and then try the input against each one in turn.

You may want to flag ambiguous inputs e.g. is 2012/5/6 the 5th June or 6th May ?

DateTimeParser[] dateParsers = {

        DateTimeFormat.forPattern("yyyy-MM-dd").getParser() };

answers.body_markdown:
Apache commons has a utility method to solve this problem . The [org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils][1] class has a method parseDateStrictly
 



       public static Date parseDateStrictly(String str,
                                             String[] parsePatterns)
                                      throws ParseException

     Parameters:
            str - the date to parse, not null
            parsePatterns - the date format patterns to use, see SimpleDateFormat, not null

 Parses a string representing a date by trying a variety of different parsers. 

The parse will try each parse pattern in turn. A parse is only deemed successful if it parses the whole of the input string. If no parse patterns match, a ParseException is thrown.

The parser parses strictly - it does not allow for dates such as "February 942, 1996".


   


  [1]: https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-2.6/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DateUtils.html#parseDateStrictly%28java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String[]%29

Parses a string representing a date by trying a variety of different parsers.

The parse will try each parse pattern in turn. A parse is only deemed successful if it parses the whole of the input string. If no parse patterns match, a ParseException is thrown.

The parser parses strictly - it does not allow for dates such as "February 942, 1996".

answers.title: How to detect the given date format using java
answers.body:
Click to see the result

Use the regex to parse the string for date. This regex can detect any kind of date format. The sample code here is not including time yet. You can change the code to add more parts of the date like time and time zone...The month name is depending on default language locale of the system.

import java.io.IOException;
import java.text.DateFormatSymbols;
import java.text.ParseException;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;
import java.util.Calendar;
import java.util.Date;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Iterator;
import java.util.regex.Matcher;
import java.util.regex.Pattern;

public class DateUtils {

    static String MONTH="";
    static String dateRegEx="";
    static Pattern DatePattern; 
    static HashMap<String, Integer> monthMap = new HashMap<String, Integer>();
    static {
        initializeMonthName();
        dateRegEx="(?i)(\\d{1,4}|"+MONTH+")[-|/|.|\\s+]?(\\d{1,2}|"+MONTH+")[-|/|.|,]?[\\s+]?(\\d{1,4}|"+MONTH+")[\\s+|\\t|T]?(\\d{0,2}):?(\\d{0,2}):?(\\d{0,2})[.|,]?[\\s]?(\\d{0,3})?([+|-])?(\\d{0,2})[:]?(\\d{0,2})[\\s+]?([A|P]M)?";
        DatePattern = Pattern.compile(dateRegEx);
    }

    private static void initializeMonthName() {
        String[] monthName=getMonthString(true);
        for(int i=0;i<12;i++){
            monthMap.put(monthName[i].toLowerCase(), Integer.valueOf(i+1));
        }

        monthName=getMonthString(false);
        for(int i=0;i<12;i++){
            monthMap.put(monthName[i].toLowerCase(), Integer.valueOf(i+1));
        }

        Iterator<String> it = monthMap.keySet().iterator();
        while(it.hasNext()){
            String month=it.next();
            if(MONTH.isEmpty()){
                MONTH=month;
            }else{
                MONTH=MONTH + "|" + month;
            }
        }
    }

    public static boolean isInteger(Object object) {
        if(object instanceof Integer) {
            return true;
        } else {
            try{
                Integer.parseInt(object.toString());
            }catch(Exception e) {
                return false;
            }           
        } 
        return true;
    }

    public static String[] getMonthString(boolean isShort) {
        DateFormatSymbols dfs = new DateFormatSymbols();
        if (isShort) {
         return dfs.getShortMonths();
        } else {
            return dfs.getMonths();
        }
    }

    public static int getMonthMap(String value) {

        if(monthMap.get(value)==null){
            return 0;
        }
        return monthMap.get(value).intValue();      
    }

    public static long parseDate(String value){

        Matcher matcher = DatePattern.matcher(value);
        int Year=0, Month=0, Day=0; 
        boolean isYearFound=false;
        boolean isMonthFound=false;
        boolean isDayFound=false;
        if(matcher.find()) {            
            for(int i=1;i<matcher.groupCount();i++){
                String data=matcher.group(i)==null?"":matcher.group(i); 
                if(data.equalsIgnoreCase("null")){
                    data="";
                }
                //System.out.println(String.valueOf(i) + ": " + data);
                switch(i){
                case 1:
                    if(!data.isEmpty()){
                        if(isInteger(data)){
                            Integer YMD = Integer.valueOf(data);
                            if(YMD==0){
                                return 0;
                            }
                            if(YMD>31){
                                Year = YMD.intValue();
                                isYearFound = true;
                            }else if(YMD>12){
                                Day = YMD.intValue();
                                isDayFound = true;
                            }else {
                                Month=YMD.intValue();
                                isMonthFound=true;
                            }
                        }else {
                            Month = getMonthMap(data.toLowerCase());
                            if(Month==0){
                                return 0;
                            }
                            isMonthFound=true;
                        }
                    }else {
                        return 0;
                    }
                    break;
                case 2:
                    if(!data.isEmpty()){
                        if(isInteger(data)){                            
                            Integer YMD = Integer.valueOf(data);
                            if(YMD==0){
                                return 0;
                            }

                            if(YMD>31){
                                if(isYearFound) {
                                    return 0;
                                }
                                Year = YMD.intValue();
                                isYearFound = true;
                            }else if(YMD>12){
                                if(isDayFound) {                                    
                                    return 0;
                                }
                                Day = YMD.intValue();
                                isDayFound = true;
                            }else {                             
                                if(isMonthFound){
                                    Day=YMD.intValue();
                                    isDayFound=true;
                                }else{
                                    Month=YMD.intValue();
                                    isMonthFound=true;
                                }
                            }
                        }else {
                            if(isMonthFound){
                                Day=Month;
                                isDayFound=true;
                            }
                            Month = getMonthMap(data.toLowerCase());
                            if(Month==0){
                                return 0;
                            }

                            isMonthFound=true;
                        }
                    }else {
                        return 0;
                    }
                    break;
                case 3:
                    if(!data.isEmpty()){
                        if(isInteger(data)){

                            Integer YMD = Integer.valueOf(data);
                            if(YMD==0){
                                return 0;
                            }
                            if(YMD>31){
                                if(isYearFound) {
                                    return 0;
                                }
                                Year = YMD.intValue();
                                isYearFound = true;
                            }else if(YMD>12){
                                if(isDayFound) {
                                    return 0;
                                }
                                Day = YMD.intValue();
                                isDayFound = true;
                            }else {
                                if(isMonthFound){
                                    Day=YMD.intValue();
                                    isDayFound=true;                                    
                                }else {
                                    Month = YMD.intValue();
                                    isMonthFound=true;
                                }

                            }
                        }else {
                            if(isMonthFound){
                                Day=Month;
                                isDayFound=true;
                            }
                            Month = getMonthMap(data.toLowerCase());
                            if(Month==0){
                                return 0;
                            }
                            isMonthFound=true;
                        }
                    }else {
                        return 0;
                    }
                    break;
                case 4:
                //hour
                    break;
                case 5:
                //minutes
                    break;
                case 6:
                //second
                    break;
                case 7:
                //millisecond
                    break;
                case 8:
                //time zone +/-
                    break;
                case 9:
                //time zone hour
                    break;
                case 10:
                // time zone minute
                    break;
                case 11:
                //AM/PM
                    break;
                }

            }           
        }

        Calendar c = Calendar.getInstance();
        c.set(Year, Month-1, Day, 0, 0); 
        return c.getTime().getTime();
    }


    public static void main(String[] argv) throws IOException {

        long d= DateUtils.parseDate("16 July 2012");
        Date dt = new Date(d);
        SimpleDateFormat df2 = new SimpleDateFormat("d MMMM yyyy");
        String dateText = df2.format(dt);
        System.out.println(dateText);

        d= DateUtils.parseDate("March 20 2012");
        dt = new Date(d);
        dateText = df2.format(dt);
        System.out.println(dateText);        

        d= DateUtils.parseDate("2012 March 20");
        dt = new Date(d);
        dateText = df2.format(dt);
        System.out.println(dateText);  
    }

}

answers.title: How to detect the given date format using java
answers.body:
public static String detectDateFormat(Context context, String inputDate, String requiredFormat) {
    String tempDate = inputDate.replace("/", "").replace("-", "").replace(" ", "");
    String dateFormat = "";

    if (tempDate.matches("([0-12]{2})([0-31]{2})([0-9]{4})")) {
        dateFormat = "MMddyyyy";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-31]{2})([0-12]{2})([0-9]{4})")) {
        dateFormat = "ddMMyyyy";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-9]{4})([0-12]{2})([0-31]{2})")) {
        dateFormat = "yyyyMMdd";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-9]{4})([0-31]{2})([0-12]{2})")) {
        dateFormat = "yyyyddMM";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-31]{2})([a-z]{3})([0-9]{4})")) {
        dateFormat = "ddMMMyyyy";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([a-z]{3})([0-31]{2})([0-9]{4})")) {
        dateFormat = "MMMddyyyy";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-9]{4})([a-z]{3})([0-31]{2})")) {
        dateFormat = "yyyyMMMdd";
    } else if (tempDate.matches("([0-9]{4})([0-31]{2})([a-z]{3})")) {
        dateFormat = "yyyyddMMM";
    } else {

    }
    try {
        String formattedDate = new SimpleDateFormat(requiredFormat, Locale.ENGLISH).format(new SimpleDateFormat(dateFormat).parse(tempDate));
        Toast.makeText(context, formattedDate, Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
        return formattedDate;
    } catch (Exception e) {
        Toast.makeText(context, "Please check the date format", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show();
        return "";
    }

}

answers.title: How to detect the given date format using java
answers.body:
My library FTA (https://github.com/tsegall/fta) is designed to solve exactly this problem (among others). Here is an example:


import java.util.Locale;

import com.cobber.fta.dates.DateTimeParser;
import com.cobber.fta.dates.DateTimeParser.DateResolutionMode;

public abstract class DetermineDateFormat {

    public static void main(final String[] args) {
        final DateTimeParser dtp = new DateTimeParser(DateResolutionMode.MonthFirst, Locale.ENGLISH);

        System.err.println(dtp.determineFormatString("26 July 2012"));
        System.err.println(dtp.determineFormatString("March 9 2012"));
        // Note: Detected as MM/dd/yyyy despite being ambiguous as we indicated MonthFirst above when insufficient data
        System.err.println(dtp.determineFormatString("07/04/2012"));
        System.err.println(dtp.determineFormatString("2012 March 20"));
        System.err.println(dtp.determineFormatString("2012/04/09 18:24:12"));
    }

Which will give the following output:

MMMM d yyyy
MM/dd/yyyy
yyyy MMMM dd
yyyy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss

            formatedDate = getDateFormat().format(date);

1. Check Chrome Version Compatibility, Clear browser datas etc.

2. Update Selenium WebDriver

3. Verify Download Settings

Go to **Settings**.
Scroll down and click on "Privacy and security" in the left sidebar.
Click on "Site settings."
Scroll down and click on "Additional content settings."
Click on "Automatic downloads."
Ensure that "Ask when a site tries to download files automatically after the first file" is not enabled.

And i can recommend  you some code change as well.

    from selenium import webdriver
    
    chrome_options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()
    chrome_options.add_experimental_option("prefs", {
        "download.default_directory": "/path/to/your/download/directory",
        "download.prompt_for_download": False,
        "download.directory_upgrade": True
    })
    
    driver = webdriver.Chrome(executable_path="/path/to/chromedriver", options=chrome_options)


**UPD**    
According to [this post][1] try removing `--incognito` from chrome options.

  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77093248/chromedriver-version-117-forces-save-as-dialog-how-to-bypass-selenium-jav?rq=1

And i can recommend you some code change as well.

from selenium import webdriver

chrome_options.add_experimental_option("prefs", {
    "download.default_directory": "/path/to/your/download/directory",
    "download.prompt_for_download": False,
    "download.directory_upgrade": True
})

driver = webdriver.Chrome(executable_path="/path/to/chromedriver", options=chrome_options)

answers.title: How to left-justify TableColumn headers programmatically? (i.e. without FXML)
answers.body:
Preface

The solution includes a full working example. There are ways to choose a column header by ID or by text value.

The tricks to know are that JavaFX creates a label inside of the table header cell and that you can find the children of a node with the method lookup() or lookupAll().

I refactored your code a little bit, so that there is a minimal example.

Solution

This is how it is done:

package com.example.demo;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.application.Platform;
import javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyObjectWrapper;
import javafx.collections.FXCollections;
import javafx.geometry.Pos;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;
import javafx.scene.control.TableColumn;
import javafx.scene.control.TableView;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.util.Base64;
import java.util.function.Function;

public class HelloApplication2 extends Application {

    private record RowData(String left, Integer right) {
    }

    @Override
    public void start(
            Stage stage) {

        TableView<RowData> table = new TableView<>();
        table.setId("myTable");
        table.getColumns().add(buildTableColumn("colLeft", "Left", RowData::left));
        table.getColumns().add(buildTableColumn("colRight", "Right", RowData::right));
        table.setItems(FXCollections.observableArrayList(
                new RowData("Left Column Header should be Left-Justified!", 123456789),
                new RowData("This Cell is left justified ok", 789),
                new RowData("Right Column Header should be Right-Justified!", 456789)));

        // Align a column
        alignColumnOfTableByColumnId(table, "#colLeft", true, false);
        alignColumnOfTableByColumnId(table, "#colRight", false, false);

        // Align a table header left by columnId without invoking stage
        //        Platform.runLater(() -> {
        //            table.lookup("#colLeft").lookupAll(".column-header > .label").forEach(label -> {
        //                ((Label) label).setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_LEFT);
        //            });
        //        });

        // Align only the table header "Left" to left by columnId
        //        Platform.runLater(() -> {
        //            stage.getScene().lookup("#colLeft").lookupAll(".column-header > .label").forEach(label -> {
        //                ((Label) label).setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_LEFT);
        //            });
        //        });

        // Align only the table header "Left" to left by label text
        //        Platform.runLater(() -> {
        //            ArrayList<Node> headerNodes = new ArrayList<>(table.lookupAll(".column-header > .label"));
        //            for (Node headerNode : headerNodes) {
        //                Label headerLabel = ((Label) headerNode);
        //                if (headerLabel.getText().equals("Left")) {
        //                    headerLabel.setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_LEFT);
        //                }
        //            }
        //        });

        // Align all table headers to left
        //        Platform.runLater(()->{
        //            table.lookupAll(".column-header > .label").forEach(node -> {
        //                System.out.println(node);
        //                ((Label) node).setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_LEFT);
        //            });
        //        });

        Scene scene = new Scene(table, 500, 200);
        stage.setTitle("Table Column Alignment");
        stage.setScene(scene);
        stage.show();
    }

    private void alignColumnOfTableByColumnId(
            TableView<RowData> table,
            String columnIdWithHashTag,
            boolean alignLeft,
            boolean alignOnlyHeader) {

        Platform.runLater(() -> {
            Pos alignment = alignLeft
                    ? Pos.CENTER_LEFT
                    : Pos.CENTER_RIGHT;
            String alignmentCells = alignLeft
                    ? "center-left"
                    : "center-right";

            table.lookup(columnIdWithHashTag).lookupAll(".column-header > .label").forEach(label -> {
                ((Label) label).setAlignment(alignment);
            });
            if (!alignOnlyHeader) {
                table.getScene().getStylesheets().add("data:text/css;base64," +
                        Base64.getEncoder()
                                .encodeToString((columnIdWithHashTag + ".table-cell {-fx-alignment: " + alignmentCells + "}")
                                        .getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8)));
            }
        });
    }


    private <T, V> TableColumn<T, V> buildTableColumn(
            String columnId,
            String title,
            Function<T, V> beanPropertyGetter) {

        TableColumn<T, V> tableColumn = new TableColumn<T, V>(title);
        tableColumn.setId(columnId);
        tableColumn.setCellValueFactory((cellDataFeatures) -> {
            T bean = cellDataFeatures.getValue();
            V beanPropertyValue = beanPropertyGetter.apply(bean);
            return new ReadOnlyObjectWrapper<V>(beanPropertyValue);
        });
        return tableColumn;
    }

    public static void main(
            final String[] args) {

        launch(args);
    }

}

items.title: How to left-justify TableColumn headers programmatically? (i.e. without FXML)
items.body:
I'm trying to left-justify TableColumn headers in JavaFX 17.

I want to do this using Java code ("programmatically").
I do not use FXML.

I can set it globally by supplying a stylesheet on the scene (base64 encoded URL), but how can I change the alignment of just one TableColumn header?

I've tried all manner of CSS via setStyle(...), but all to no avail.

Here is my preferred solution:

Many, many thanks to @DavidWeber for all his help. I've incorporated his suggestions.
(and used a JDK switch/null Preview Feature)
The original question code is further down.

package com.stackoverflow.question;

import java.util.function.Function;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.application.Platform;
import javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyObjectWrapper;
import javafx.collections.FXCollections;
import javafx.collections.transformation.SortedList;
import javafx.geometry.Pos;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;
import javafx.scene.control.TableColumn;
import javafx.scene.control.TableView;
import javafx.scene.control.skin.TableColumnHeader;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public final class TableColumnAlignment extends Application {

    private record RowData(String left, Integer right) {}

    private static final String TITLE_LEFT  = "Left";
    private static final String TITLE_RIGHT = "Right";

    @Override
    public void start(final Stage stage) throws Exception {

        final var colLeft  = buildColumn("colLeft",  TITLE_LEFT,  RowData :: left);
        final var colRight = buildColumn("colRight", TITLE_RIGHT, RowData :: right);
        ;         colRight.setStyle("-fx-alignment: center-right");
        /*
         * TODO See above for TableColumn alignment
         */
        final var sortedList = new SortedList<RowData>(FXCollections.observableArrayList(FXCollections.observableArrayList(
                new RowData("Left Column Header should be Left-Justified!", 123456789),
                new RowData("This Cell is left justified ok",                     789),
                new RowData("Right Column Header should be Right-Justified!",  456789) )));

        final var  table    = new TableView<RowData>();
        ;          table.getColumns().add(colLeft);
        ;          table.getColumns().add(colRight);
        ;          table.setItems(sortedList);
        /*
         * Now make sure, when the Table is "unsorted", it reverts to its original order...
         */
        sortedList.comparatorProperty().bind(table.comparatorProperty());
        /*
         * TODO See below for TableColumnHeader alignment
         */
        Platform.runLater(() -> {
            table.lookupAll(".column-header > .label").forEach(node -> {
                if (node.getParent()  instanceof  TableColumnHeader
                &&  node              instanceof  Label              nodeLabel) {
                    switch(nodeLabel.getText()) {
                        case TITLE_LEFT  -> nodeLabel.setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_LEFT);
                        case TITLE_RIGHT -> nodeLabel.setAlignment(Pos.CENTER_RIGHT);
                    }
                    System.out.println(nodeLabel + "\t" + nodeLabel.getText());
                }
            });
        });
        stage.setTitle("Table Column Alignment");
        stage.setScene(new Scene(table, 500, 200));
        stage.show();
    }

    private <T, V> TableColumn<T, V> buildColumn(final String id, final String title, final Function<T, V> getter) {

        final var tableColumn = new TableColumn<T, V>(title);
        ;         tableColumn.setId(id);
        ;         tableColumn.setCellValueFactory((cellDataFeatures) -> {

            final T bean              = cellDataFeatures.getValue();
            final V beanPropertyValue = getter.apply(bean);

            return new ReadOnlyObjectWrapper<V>(beanPropertyValue);
        });
        return    tableColumn;
    }

    public static void main(final String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }
}

Here's the original code for the Question:

package com.stackoverflow.question;

import java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets;
import java.util.Base64;
import java.util.function.Function;

import javafx.application.Application;
import javafx.beans.property.ReadOnlyObjectWrapper;
import javafx.collections.FXCollections;
import javafx.collections.ObservableList;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.scene.control.TableColumn;
import javafx.scene.control.TableView;
import javafx.stage.Stage;

public final class TableColumnAlignment extends Application {

    private record RowData(String left, Integer right) {}

    @Override
    public void start(final Stage stage) throws Exception {

        final var       colLeft  = buildTableColumn("Left",  RowData :: left);
        final var       colRight = buildTableColumn("Right", RowData :: right);

        colLeft .setId("colLeft");
        colRight.setId("colRight");
        /*
         * TODO The following sets the Column colour (including Header) but has no effect on alignment
         */
        colLeft.setStyle("-fx-alignment: center-left; -fx-background-color: yellow");

        final var  table    = new TableView<RowData>();
        addColumns(table.getColumns(), colLeft, colRight);
        ;          table.setItems(FXCollections.observableArrayList(
                new RowData("Left Column Header should be Left-Justified!", 123456789),
                new RowData("This Cell is left justified ok",                     789),
                new RowData("Right Column Header should be Right-Justified!",  456789) ));

        final var  scene    = new Scene(table, 500, 200);
//      ;          scene.getStylesheets().add(encodeStyleAsURL(".column-header .label {-fx-alignment: center-left}"));
        /*
         * TODO The previous line, when uncommented, left-justifies ALL Column-Headers
         */
        stage.setTitle("Table Column Alignment");
        stage.setScene(scene);
        stage.show();
    }

    public  static String encodeStyleAsURL(final String cssStyle) {

        final var cssBytes       = cssStyle.getBytes(StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
        final var cssBytesBase64 = Base64.getEncoder().encodeToString(cssBytes);

        return    "data:text/css;base64," + cssBytesBase64;
    }

    private <T, V> TableColumn<T, V> buildTableColumn(final String title, final Function<T, V> beanPropertyGetter) {

        final var tableColumn = new TableColumn<T, V>(title);
        ;         tableColumn.setCellValueFactory((cellDataFeatures) -> {

            final T bean              = cellDataFeatures.getValue();
            final V beanPropertyValue = beanPropertyGetter.apply(bean);

            return new ReadOnlyObjectWrapper<V>(beanPropertyValue);
        });
        return    tableColumn;
    }

    @SafeVarargs
    private final <T> void addColumns(final ObservableList<TableColumn<T, ?>> columnList, final TableColumn<T, ?>... columns) {
        columnList.addAll(columns);
    }

    public static void main(final String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }
}

answers.body_markdown: You're supposed to store data, not methods. You can run that calculation in the layer above. The entity class is supposed to be a POJO and the annotation `@Field("averageFare")` can be added on the field itself rather than on the method. You can have the method you show as a utility method which would always get you the average `on the fly` rather than store it in the db. If you need it stored, just add the `averageFare` instance type **field** and in the setter you can perform that calculation - then you don't need the getter calculations anymore.
answers.title: How can I get spring data to save a "getter" as a mongodb field?
answers.body: You're supposed to store data, not methods. You can run that calculation in the layer above. The entity class is supposed to be a POJO and the annotation @Field("averageFare") can be added on the field itself rather than on the method. You can have the method you show as a utility method which would always get you the average on the fly rather than store it in the db. If you need it stored, just add the averageFare instance type field and in the setter you can perform that calculation - then you don't need the getter calculations anymore.

answers.title: How can I get spring data to save a "getter" as a mongodb field?
answers.body:
Move the calculation logic from getter to setter. It assures the field has its value as intended and the repository operates with the calculated data.

@Field("averageFare")
String averageFare;

public void setAverageFare(BigDecimal averageFare) {
    if (averageFare == null || this.averageFare == null || this.fareTotal == null) {
        // set if the calculation would fail on NPE
        this.averageFare = averageFare;
    } else {
        // otherwise perform the calculation
        this.averageFare = this.fareTotal.divide(
                BigDecimal.valueOf(getCount()), 
                RoundingMode.HALF_EVEN); 
    }
}

public BigDecimal getAverageFare() {
    return averageFare;
}

answers.title: How can I get spring data to save a "getter" as a mongodb field?
answers.body:
You can do this:

  1. Define the field 'averageFare' in the POJO (as any other member)

private BigDecimal averageFare;
  1. Create the method to calculate its value

public void calculateAverageFare() {
  this.averageFare = this.fareTotal.divide(BigDecimal.valueOf(getCount()), RoundingMode.HALF_EVEN);
}
  1. Create a custom Mongo event listener

package your.package;

import org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.mapping.event.AbstractMongoEventListener;
import org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.mapping.event.BeforeConvertEvent;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

@Component
public class YourEntityListener extends AbstractMongoEventListener {
  @Override
  public void onBeforeConvert(BeforeConvertEvent event) {
    super.onBeforeConvert(event);
    YourEntity entity = event.getSource();
    entity.calculateAverageFare();
  }
}

Thus, each time th documebnt is is updated, the calculated field will be automatically persisted in the DB.

comments.body_markdown: Is the delete query printed in the logs?
comments.body: Is the delete query printed in the logs?

comments.body_markdown: There won't be a delete query if you have the Product or User that reference it in the persistence unit. As Flydog answer hinted at, the relationships from Product->Review and User->Review are cascade all, which means that any Review found in those lists will be persisted to the database. So you cannot delete a review without first removing it from those collections as JPA will just find it there and re-persist it, canceling out the delete operation or (at times) being worse and issuing the delete and then re-inserting it.
comments.body: There won't be a delete query if you have the Product or User that reference it in the persistence unit. As Flydog answer hinted at, the relationships from Product->Review and User->Review are cascade all, which means that any Review found in those lists will be persisted to the database. So you cannot delete a review without first removing it from those collections as JPA will just find it there and re-persist it, canceling out the delete operation or (at times) being worse and issuing the delete and then re-inserting it.

comments.body_markdown: You must maintain bidirectional relationships and ensure both sides are in synch with what you want in the database yourself. You might get by if the User and Product's 'review' lists aren't loaded, but safest strategy is always to maintain the collections yourself and remove their reference to the Review you want to delete before deleting it. JPA can have various levels of caching, so it'll save you problems down the line to just always keep objects in synch.

You might get by if the User and Product's 'review' lists aren't loaded, but safest strategy is always to maintain the collections yourself and remove their reference to the Review you want to delete before deleting it. JPA can have various levels of caching, so it'll save you problems down the line to just always keep objects in synch.

comments.body_markdown: "DELETE FROM review_postgresql r WHERE r.id = :id" isn't going to work unless you don't have anything (votes) referencing that review. Cascade delete only work on objects - so votes will be left behind when using JPQL or SQL queries directly. If nothing is being done at all - you are likely not running this in a transaction.
comments.body: "DELETE FROM review_postgresql r WHERE r.id = :id" isn't going to work unless you don't have anything (votes) referencing that review. Cascade delete only work on objects - so votes will be left behind when using JPQL or SQL queries directly. If nothing is being done at all - you are likely not running this in a transaction.

answers.body_markdown:
1. The problem might be caused by the bidirectional relationships between the entities, which require synchronization of both sides when performing operations.
2. To delete a Review entity, you need to remove it from the Product and User entities that reference it, otherwise the foreign key constraints will prevent the deletion.
3. You can use orphanRemoval = true in the @OneToMany annotations of Product and User entities to automatically delete the Review entity when it is removed from the collections.
4. Alternatively, you can use entityManager.remove (review) instead of tokenRepository.delete (review), which will cascade the removal operation to the associated entities.
answers.title: Spring JPA not deleting entity
answers.body:
1. The problem might be caused by the bidirectional relationships between the entities, which require synchronization of both sides when performing operations.
  2. To delete a Review entity, you need to remove it from the Product and User entities that reference it, otherwise the foreign key constraints will prevent the deletion.
  3. You can use orphanRemoval = true in the @OneToMany annotations of Product and User entities to automatically delete the Review entity when it is removed from the collections.
  4. Alternatively, you can use entityManager.remove (review) instead of tokenRepository.delete (review), which will cascade the removal operation to the associated entities.

items.title: Spring JPA not deleting entity
items.body:
When I try to delete a review, nothing is deleted and nothing is thrown. I've already tried changing some of the cascade types but at the moment I can't figure out what the problem is. At first, I was using the delete method provided by 'CrudRepository', where you have to pass the object reference instead of deleting by Id, but it didn't work also.

Entities

@Entity(name = "product_postgresql")
@Getter
public class Product {

    @Id
    @Column(nullable = false, unique = true)
    private String sku;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String designation;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String description;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private double aggregatedRating;

    @OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy = "product", fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    private List<Review> reviews;

    protected Product() {
    }

    public Product(final String sku, final String designation, final String description, final double aggregatedRating) {
        this.sku = sku;
        this.designation = designation;
        this.description = description;
        this.aggregatedRating = aggregatedRating;
    }
}


@Getter
@Entity(name = "review_postgresql")
public class Review {

    @Id
    private String id;

    @Version
    private long version;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String approvalStatus;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String text;

    @OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy = "review", fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @Setter
    private List<Vote> votes;

    private String report;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private LocalDate publishingDate;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String funFact;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private double rating;

    @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.EAGER, cascade = CascadeType.REFRESH)
    @JoinColumn(name = "product_sku", nullable = false)
    private Product product;

    @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.EAGER, cascade = CascadeType.REFRESH)
    @JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
    private User user;

    protected Review() {
    }

    public Review(final String id, final long version, final String approvalStatus, final String text,
                  final String report, final LocalDate publishingDate, final String funFact, final Double rating,

        this.id = id;

        this.text = text;
        this.report = report;
        this.publishingDate = publishingDate;
        this.funFact = funFact;
        this.rating = rating;
        this.product = product;
        this.user = user;

}

@Entity(name = "vote_postgresql")
@Getter
public class Vote implements Serializable {

    @EmbeddedId
    private VoteKey id;

    @Column(nullable = false)
    private String vote;

    @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    @MapsId("user_id")
    @JoinColumn(name = "user_id", nullable = false)
    private User user;

    @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    @MapsId("review_id")
    @JoinColumn(name = "review_id", nullable = false)
    private Review review;

    protected Vote() {
    }

    public Vote(User user, Review review, String vote) {
        this.id = new VoteKey(user.getId(), review.getId());
        this.user = user;
        this.review = review;
        this.vote = vote;
    }
}

JPA Repository

@ConditionalOnProperty(value="spring.repositories.targetPackage", havingValue = "postgresql")
public interface ReviewRepositoryPostgresql extends CrudRepository<Review, String> {
    @Modifying
    @Query("DELETE FROM review_postgresql r WHERE r.id = :id")
    void deleteById(String id);
}

answers.title: Selenium how to disable chrome Save Address prompt?
answers.body:
To disable notification in Chrome browser client take you can use a setExperimentalOption() passing there a HashMap containing profile.default_content_setting_values.notifications with Value of 2, as following:

System.setProperty("webdriver.chrome.driver", "C:\\path\\to\\chromedriver.exe");
Map<String, Object> prefs = new HashMap<String, Object>();
prefs.put("profile.default_content_setting_values.notifications", 2);
prefs.put("credentials_enable_service", false);
prefs.put("profile.password_manager_enabled", false);
ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions();
options.setExperimentalOption("prefs", prefs);
options.addArguments("start-maximized");
options.addArguments("disable-infobars");
options.addArguments("--disable-extensions");
options.addArguments("--disable-notifications");
WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(options);

answers.title: Selenium how to disable chrome Save Address prompt?
answers.body:
Now, I found this to work in Selenium Java

ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions();
Map<String, Object> prefs = new HashMap<String, Object>();
prefs.put("profile.default_content_setting_values.notifications", 2);
prefs.put("autofill.profile_enabled", false);
options.setExperimentalOption("prefs", prefs);

WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(options);

answers.body_markdown: You should make the endpoint a dynamic property in application.properties file and externalize it to github or any other secure and remote location that can be accessible by your application using a config server. That is create a config server application and make your application a config client. This way if the endpoint changes, update your externalized property in github ( if you are using github as remote location) without redeploying your springboot application

answers.title: Creating a 2D array of coordinates in java
answers.body:
I am not able to get much from your explanation but I am showing you two full examples with Coordinates class and without:

example 1, with you setCoordinate function that returns the Coordinates object:

package com.company;

import java.io.Console;
import java.util.concurrent.ThreadLocalRandom;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
    // write your code here

        Coordinates[] coord = new Coordinates[20];

        createMap();
    }

    public static void createMap(){
        Coordinates[] coord = new Coordinates[20];

        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i ++){
            coord[i] = setCoordinates(ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, 99) + 1, ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, 99) + 1);
        }

        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i ++){
            coord[i].getCoord();
        }
    }

    public static Coordinates setCoordinates (int row, int column){
        Coordinates c = new Coordinates();
        c.setRow(row);
        c.setColumn(column);
        return c;
    }

    public static class Coordinates {
        int row;
        int column;

        public Coordinates(){
            //constructor
        }

        public void setColumn(int column){
            this.column = column;
        }

        public void setRow(int row){
            this.row = row;
        }

        public int getRow(){
            return row;
        }

        public int getColumn(){
            return column;
        }

        public void getCoord(){
            //just return and print the coordinates
            System.out.println("ROW: " + this.getRow() + "      COL: " + this.getColumn());
            //change void to return and return value if you like :)
        }

    }
}

if you want you can play around with the getCoord() and return array of coordinates by knowing that [0] is row and [1] is column like this:

public int[] getCoord()
        {
            int coords[] = new int[2];

            coords[0] = this.getRow();
            coords[1] = this.getColumn();

            return coords;
        }

and then you can print this like this

for(int i = 0; i < 20; i ++){
            int coords[] = coord[i].getCoord();
            System.out.println(coords[0] + " - " + coords[1]);
        }

and example 2, without returning Coordinates

package com.company;

import java.io.Console;
import java.util.concurrent.ThreadLocalRandom;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
    // write your code here

        Coordinates[] coord = new Coordinates[20];

        createMap();
    }

    public static void createMap(){
        Coordinates[] coord = new Coordinates[20];

        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i ++){
            coord[i].setCoordinates(ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, 99) + 1, ThreadLocalRandom.current().nextInt(0, 99) + 1);
        }

        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i ++){
            coord[i].getCoord();
        }
    }

    public static class Coordinates {
        int row;
        int column;

        public Coordinates(){
            //constructor
        }

        public void setColumn(int column){
            this.column = column;
        }

        public void setRow(int row){
            this.row = row;
        }

        public int getRow(){
            return row;
        }

        public int getColumn(){
            return column;
        }

        public void setCoordinates (int row, int column){
            this.setRow(row);
            this.setColumn(column);
        }

        public void getCoord(){
            //just return and print the coordinates
            System.out.println("ROW: " + this.getRow() + "      COL: " + this.getColumn());
            //change void to return and return value if you like :)
        }

    }
}

answers.title: ASPX Form DoPostBack with Java and Selenium
answers.body:
So after months of trial and error, I stumbled upon this YouTube Video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pZjz050TBA

In this video Prakash Narkhede walks through the stepping of xpath layers to arrive at the specific element he is searching for. My first challenge was understanding where in the DevTools he was entering the search criteria to evaluate the xpath - this was simply f to 'find' the elements in the DOM (simple but was confusing at the time).

Next I navigated as he did entering each node down to where I was trying to find the element I needed to click. The following xpath:

"//div[@class='deptparagraphdescription2']/p[@class='center_align']/a"

finally got click to work w/ the following code (Note: Challenging page url found in code below as well:

public static void Main() {
    WebElement WE;
    WebDriver WD;

    System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver", "/home/ms/Development/WS/WebScrape/src-fl/geckodriver/geckodriver");
    System.setProperty("webdirver.firfox.bin", "/usr/bin/firefox");

    // Fire Up Firefox Browser
    WD = new FirefoxDriver();

    // Navigate to Target Site / specific page where object can NOT be clicked ('Accept button')
    L.SendLog("Running", "Testing", "JETesting", "Main", "Navigating to problem page", "");
    WD.get("https://app02.clerk.org/cm_rpt/?id=fci");
    L.SendLog("Running", "Testing", "JETesting", "Main", "Navigation to problem page completed", "");

    try {
        L.SendLog("Running", "Testing", "JETesting", "Main", "Attempting to select and click element by using xpath '//div[@class='deptparagraphdescription2']/p[@class='center_align']/a'", "");
        WebDriverWait wait;
        wait = new WebDriverWait(WD, Duration.ofSeconds(30));

        WE = wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(WD.findElement(By.xpath("//div[@class='deptparagraphdescription2']/p[@class='center_align']/a"))));
        WE.click();
        s = "pause for breakpoint";
    } catch (Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
        L.SendLog("Running", "Testing", "JETesting", "Main", "Clicking by xpath '//div[@class='deptparagraphdescription2']/p[@class='center_align']/a' FAILED", e.getMessage());
        s = "pause for breakpoint";
    }
}

Traversing the path as Prakash did in his video, helped ID an xpath for the anchor () element to allow the click to work. Simply copying the xpath for what I believed was the element to select and click on didn't work. Selecting an xpath via the traversal path technique seemed to solve the problem.

items.title: ASPX Form DoPostBack with Java and Selenium
items.body:
Test Scenario:

  1. Navigate to target site
  2. Select hyperlink and advance to 2nd page
  3. Select hyperlink on 2nd page and advance to 3rd page
  4. Click on "Accept" button to advance to following page

The Accept Page has a doPostBack javascript hyperlink and I'm unable to use xpath, javascriptExecutor, or any other means to advance to the next page.

Code in question w/ inline comments:

public static void Main ()  {
WebElement      WE;
WebDriver   WD;
WebDriverWait   WW;

System.setProperty("webdriver.gecko.driver", "MyPathTo/geckodriver");
System.setProperty("webdirver.firfox.bin", "/usr/bin/firefox");

//Fire Up Firefox Browser
WD  =   new FirefoxDriver();

//Navigate to Target Site
WD.get("https://MyFakeSite.org");

//Find first link / page to navigate to from site
WE   =  WD.findElement(By.xpath("/html/body/form/div[6]/div[1]/div/div[2]/div/div[2]/a"));
WD.get(WE.getAttribute("href"));

//Find second link / page to navigate to from current page
WE   = WD.findElement(By.xpath("/html/body/form/div[5]/div/div[2]/div[3]/div/span[2]/div[4]/a"));
WE.click();

//Train falls off the rails here:
try
{
WebDriverWait   wait;
wait   =   new WebDriverWait(WD,Duration.ofSeconds(30));

//Error occurs with this line
wait.until(ExpectedConditions.elementToBeClickable(WD.findElement(By.xpath("//*[@id=\"ctl00_Content1_button_accept\"]"))));

WE = WD.findElement(By.xpath("//[@id='ctl00_Content1_button_accept']")); 
//Never Reach this line - Error occurs and jumps to Catch...
WE.click(); 

}

Selenium can NOT find the element and results in an error: Unable to locate element: //[@id="ctl00_Content1_button_accept"]. Since Selenium can not find the element. I originally believe the code was erroring out on the following executable line from the error line above, but stand corrected. user @pcalkins attempted to help me suggesting I was on the right path - @pacalkins suggested an xpath w/ an "a" instead of the "*" - I tried that it did not work; same result / error message. An inspection of the html code using dev tools shows this:

<a id="ctl00_Content1_button_accept" class="button_imaged" onfocus="highlight(this);" onblur="doBlur(this);" href="javascript:__doPostBack('ctl00$Content1$button_accept','')"><img id="ctl00_Content1_Image2" src="images/icons/page_go.png" align="absmiddle">
      Accept</a>

Research into the network payload has been discouraged as the form should be automatically sending the payload / variables / necessary parameters if I can just get the "Accept" button to click. I've tried WebDriver, WebElement, JavascriptExecutor, send keys (with enter key - performing the manual task of hitting the enter key on the keyboard works / advances you, but not when you send the keystrokes programmatically).

What do I do ? What is the code that will work ? Who can help me ? And a big thanks to @pcalkins for trying to help me out !!!

items.title: Mockito 5.0.0 Static Mocking Exception
items.body:
I am getting the following exception when trying to mock the static method.

static mocking is already registered in the current thread To create a new mock, the existing static mock registration must be deregistered

public class MockitoTest {

MockedStatic<MyProperties> myPropertiesMockedStatic;

@Mock;
Student student;

@BeforeClass(groups = {"mocks"})
public void setup() {
    MockitoAnnotations.openMocks(this);
    myPropertiesMockedStatic=Mockito.mockStatic(MyProperties.class);
    myPropertiesMockedStatic.when(() -> MyProperties.getProperty("document.abc.Id")).thenReturn("souJobId");

}

@Test(groups = {"mocks"})
public void testJobId() {
    try(MockedStatic<MyProperties> properties =Mockito.mockStatic(MyProperties.class)) {
        properties.when(()->MyProperties.getProperty("abc.url")).thenReturn("url");
        student.getStudentData();
    }
}
@Test(groups = {"mocks"})
public void testData(){
        myPropertiesMockedStatic.when(()->MyProperties.getProperty("abc.url")).thenReturn("testUrl");

        List<Student> list = new ArrayList<>();
        Student st = new Student();
        list.add(st);
        //todo
   
}
@AfterClass(groups = {"mocks"})
public void cleanUp(){
    myPropertiesMockedStatic.close();
}

}

I'm a running multiple tests in different classes, the way we are using the myProperties individually then run fine, but when I run all of them at once, I get For com.test.MyProperties, static mocking is already registered in the current thread. To create a new mock, the existing static mocking must be deregistered.

Is there any another way I can configure the , or is there a way to resolve this? I tried using different variable names for each of them but that doesn't work. Also tried close() on them after the test, but that doesn't seem to work, still getting getting the same issue for every classes. If there's a way to do this via Mockito, without a try-with-resources for multiple objects and their behaviour, that would work for me as well.

Thanks in advance!
